subject: Languages
title: The Greek Alphabet Revolution
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Greek Alphabet Revolution.

hook.text: The Greeks borrowed the Phoenician alphabet and made one brilliant addition: vowels.

buildup.text: Phoenician script, like Hebrew and Arabic, wrote only consonants. Readers guessed the vowels.

discovery.text: Greeks repurposed unused Phoenician consonant letters as vowels â€” A, E, I, O, U were born.

twist.text: Adding vowels made reading unambiguous for the first time â€” you didn't need to already know the word.

climax.text: This innovation spread to Latin, Cyrillic, and eventually to the alphabet you're reading right now.

punchline.text: The entire Western alphabet exists because Greeks added five letters.

quiz.question: What innovation did the Greeks add to the Phoenician alphabet?
